comment.author: 63191264@N00
comment._content:
Born 20th October 1883 London, George Valentine Williams is recorded in the 1891 as living at 4 St Quintin Avenue, Kensington, London [the property still exists], with his parents George W [sic] [b.1840 London], Matilda A [b.1849 ? Ireland] and five sisters; Blanche F [b.1873 Paris, France], Matilda B [b.1878 London], Violet M [b.1880 London], Lynworth [sic] C [b.1882 London] and Mildred A [b.1887 London] along with his mother’s brother and three domestic servants. His father’s occupation is given as “Editor in Chief – unreadable”
A version of his family tree on Ancestry.com gives his father’s name as George Douglas Williams and lists other siblings; Frederick S [b.1882] and Douglas [b.1892]. The name Lynworth is a transcription error, the name being Hyacinth C. 
Additional information is his marriage to Alice Crawford, the date is not given.
 He died on 20th November 1946.

comment.author: 16830149@N02
comment._content: George V Williams married Alice Crawford in the second quarter of 1916 - Reg District St. George, Hanover Square, London.

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: Journalist, actor, lecturer, screenwriter. He created "The Fox" (Baron Alexis de Bahl), "Clubfoot" (Dr Adolph Grunt), Mr Treadgold the tailor and Detective Sergeant Trevor Dene. He also wrote one book under the name Valentine Douglas. His autobiography "The World of Action" (London: Hamish Hamilton, 1938), describes his career and journalistic adventures. For bibliography of books written 1918-1946 by George Valentine Williams see gadetection.pbworks.com/w/page/7932483/Williams,%20Valentine Several are free ebooks that can be read online. Quoting from 'American theatre: a chronicle of comedy and drama, 1930-1969, Volume 3' By Gerald Martin Bordman (Google books) Valentine Williams's story "The Crouching Beast" was turned by Williams and Alice Crawford into 'Berlin' (12-30-31, George M. Cohan), an American spy thriller about English agents in prewar Germany. Filmography includes "Despatch from Reuters" a 1940 biographical film about Paul Reuter, the man who built the famous news service that bears his name. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Dispatch_from_Reuter%27s www.fandango.com/valentinewilliams/filmography/p311855 Other works www.imdb.com/name/nm0931866/otherworks

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: 5 National Gallery portraits by Bassano of Valentine Williams (1883-1946), journalist. author and diplomat, including two with his wife, Australian actress Alice Crawford (1882-1931). www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person.php?sText=valent...

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: Brief Biography WILLIAMS, (George) Valentine. Also wrote as Douglas Valentine. British. Born 20 October 1883. Educated at Downside School; studied in Germany. Served as a Lieutenant in the Irish Guards, 1915: Military Cross (twice wounded); with the Guards Division Staff, London, 1918-19; did confidential work for the Foreign Office, London, 1939-41, and at British Embassy, Washington, D.C., 1941-42; Member of the Political Warfare Department. Woburn Abbey, Bedfordshire, 1942-45. Married Alice Crawford. Sub-Editor, 1902-03, and Berlin Correspondent, 1904-09, Renter's news agency; Journalist for the Daily Mail, London, from 1909: Paris Correspondent, 1909-13, Special Correspondent during Portuguese Revolution, 1910, reported Balkan War, 1913, first accredited correspondent to British General Headquarters. 1915. in charge of staff, Versailles Peace Conference. 1919, and later Foreign Editor; free-lance journalist in North Africa and United States during 1930's and 1940Y Chevalier, Order of the Crown of Belgium. Died 20 November 1946. www.detective-fiction.com/valentine-williams.htm Died in New York City www.imdb.com/name/nm0931866/bio
